awd_titl_txt: Synaptic Organization and Function of Reticulospinal Sensorimotor Pathways
awd_abstract_narration: This research seeks to determine how reticulospinal neurons mediate sensorimotor behavior. Sensorimotor behavior is any motor action that is guided by a sensory stimulus, for example, an itch guiding the hand to the correct spot to scratch. This requires three general steps in the nervous system. In the first step, the brain receives information about the stimulus through sensory nerves. In the last step, neurons in the brain send outputs to the spinal cord that specify muscle contractions. The middle step, which is the focus of this research, is the transformation of sensory signals into the appropriate motor signals. Hindbrain reticulospinal neurons receive sensory input and project axons to the spinal cord, but their function is not well understood. A detailed map of the synaptic inputs and outputs of reticulospinal neurons will be generated with the goal of answering two specific questions: 1. Do different reticulospinal neurons process information about different parts of the body?, and 2. Do specific reticulospinal neurons always connect to the same types of spinal neurons? Zebrafish larvae offer unique technical advantages for these studies, and since reticulospinal neurons have similar features across all vertebrates, what is learned in zebrafish may be applicable to other animals. The methods used will include neuroanatomy, neurophysiological recording, analysis of behavior, and computational modeling of neural circuits. Obtaining a detailed map of reticulospinal synaptic connections would not be feasible in other vertebrates, so this research has the potential to reveal new principles of reticulospinal sensorimotor function. This project will also have many positive impacts on education and student training at Humboldt State University. These include providing four students each semester with paid research assistantships, instituting a new course in cellular neuroscience, and making a confocal microscope system available to other faculty researchers.

Scientific outcomes:

This project aimed to learn how neural circuits in the hindbrain convert sensory inputs into ‘correct’ motor outputs, such as when an itch correctly guides a hand movement to scratch it. The hindbrain receives touch, vision, hearing, and vestibular sensory inputs, and ‘descending’ hindbrain neurons send motor output signals to the spinal cord. We studied this neural circuit in zebrafish because it is homologous to the human circuit and because tools are available for visualizing these neurons and connections in intact animals. We specifically aimed to determine whether sensations arising from different locations on the body activate different descending hindbrain neurons. Methods included (a) anatomical tracing of lateral line and trigeminal sensory nerve connections to the hindbrain, (b) determining whether different descending neurons were activated by stimulation of different body locations, (c) creating a computer model of the neural connections within these sensorimotor pathways (d) ablating lateral line hair cells and studying the effects on behavior. Progress was made on all of these goals for the lateral line system, however, trigeminal system experiments were unsuccessful.  Our main discoveries were:

-The lateral line is activated by the animal’s own movement (proprioception) and those signals contribute to motor control. This was only evident in larvae older than 14 days, a new finding about hindbrain circuit development.

-Stimulation of lateral line sensory neurons at different points along the anterior-posterior body axis activates different descending neurons, suggesting that different hindbrain neurons code for different body locations.

-Computational modeling showed that the sensorimotor reflex pathway from the lateral line to the hindbrain and spinal cord is comprised of approximately 2,616 neurons and 167,114 synaptic connections, with connection properties (local clustering and short path lengths between distant clusters) consistent with findings in other complex networks. (The model we created is available online for other researchers.)

Discoveries were also made through studies that were extensions to the stated grant aims and were supported by award resources, most significantly:

-Dopamine and serotonin modulate responses of descending neurons to lateral line stimulation.

-A genetic mutation that increases baseline cortisol levels in larval zebrafish results in increased stress behavior, an effect that is reversible by treatment with serotonin reuptake inhibitors. This result offered new insight into cortisol-serotonin co-regulation in stress-related disorders such as depression.

-Exposing zebrafish larvae to the Parksinon’s drug, L-DOPA, which raises dopamine levels, alters spontaneous movements and may damage dopamine neurons in the brain through the oxidative effects of the dopamine metabolite, dopamine aldehyde.

 

Institutional outcomes:

The award enabled the principle investigator to establish a neuroscience research laboratory at Humboldt State University in a building that opened the year the award began. Previously, there were few neuroscience resources at Humboldt State. The award funded research instruments, including a confocal microscope, that were critical for the project and continue to serve as valuable research infrastructure for the University. Several other research groups on campus routinely use these instruments. The lab outfitted for this project also serves as a valuable teaching resource, with the instruments and the scientific content of the project forming the basis of several lab exercises taught yearly in the investigator’s courses.
